Project Name: Women Against Violence Against Women (WAVAW) Collection
Name.subject: Women Against Violence Against Women
Title: Campaigns - Other
Description.note: Women Against Violence Against Women Collection: Box 5, 1 Folder; Box 9, 24 Folders.|~|Hillside Strangler memorial demonstration and related correspondence and notes. Correspondence between WAVAW, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and U.S. Congressman Edward Roybal re the "Self-Defense" advertising campaign undertaken by Max Factor to promote a new line of cosmetics. Copy of letter sent to Ellen Willis, copy of record reviewer Bruce Dancis' "In These Times" article about WAVAW and copy of response from WAVAW that appeared in March 12, 1979 edition of "In These Times." Press coverage of the Playboy sponsored Hugh M. Hefner First Amendment Awards and press releases and statements for the "WAVAW Hugh Hefner Spirit of Playboy Awards," sponsored by WAVAW, Women Against Violence in Pornography and Media (WAVPM), and Women Against Pornography (WAP). Letters of protest against adult video games such as "Custer's Revenge," "Bachelor Party," and "Beat'em and Eat'em" produced by American Multiple Industries (AMI), response letters from AMI, press releases and publicity articles. Campaigns including: Beulah Land, Dressed to Kill, Bloodline, Windows, Tattoo, Firehouse Rape, Heaven Sent, The Eyes Have It, Killing Us Softly, Seduction, 9 1/2 Weeks, Pieces.
